docs.lead_paragraph: Gaining even a sliver of Hispanic-American support could be crucial to either party in the presidential election, but especially to the Republican ticket, which is aiming its pitch in part at women.

docs.lead_paragraph: A letter printed in a Church of St. Catherine of Siena bulletin endorsed Mitt Romney for president, prompting a complaint with the I.R.S. and a petition with more than 20,000 signatures.

headline.seo: Romney Endorsement in Church Bulletin Raises Outcry
headline.main: Priest’s Dip Into Politics Raises Outcry
headline.print_headline: Priest’s Dip Into Politics Raises Outcry

docs.abstract: Jim Dwyer About New York column on letter, endorsing Mitt Romney for president, that was included in a weekly church bulletin at Church of St Catherine of Siena on Manhattan's Upper East Side; letter, which sparked petitions and a complaint to the Internal Revenue Service, has been withdrawn by church pastor Rev Jordan Kelly, who says its distribution was simply an unfortunate error in judgment.
docs.snippet: A letter printed in a Church of St. Catherine of Siena bulletin endorsed Mitt Romney for president, prompting a complaint with the I.R.S. and a petition with more than 20,000 signatures.

docs.lead_paragraph: Maybe the way to start building a consensus about how much people should be taxed is to make the connection between the taxes people pay and the benefits they finance.
docs.abstract: Eduardo Porter Economic Scene column notes that public opinion about tax policy becomes especially polarized during presidential elections; suggests that one way to build consensus would be to help voters make better connections between taxes and the benefits they service.
docs.snippet: Maybe the way to start building a consensus about how much people should be taxed is to make the connection between the taxes people pay and the benefits they finance.

headline.main: What Bush Knew, and Romney Doesn't

docs.abstract: The Republican nominee has failed to distance himself from his predecessor's failures, but he's also failed to imitate his successes.
docs.snippet: The Republican nominee has failed to distance himself from his predecessor's failures, but he's also failed to imitate his successes.

headline.main: Does Long-Term Care Insurance at a Young Age Make Sense?

docs.abstract: Younger people are buying long-term care insurance, but there are many risks for those who are not certain they're committed for the long haul.

docs.lead_paragraph: The White House says that those young illegal immigrants who will be eligible for delayed deportation will not be covered under the new health care law.

headline.seo: Limits Placed on Immigrants in Health Care Law
headline.main: Limits Placed on Immigrants in Health Care Law
headline.print_headline: Limits Placed On Immigrants In Health Law

docs.abstract: Young illegal immigrants granted deportation relief are not eligible for health insurance coverage under Pres Obama's health care overhaul; administration officials view the immigration initiative and health coverage as separate matters, but many advocates for Hispanic Americans and immigrants are infuriated because they say the restrictions are at odds with Obama's praise of young immigrants.

docs.lead_paragraph: Did you hear about Mitt Romney’s comments from a fund-raiser earlier this year? They seemed to suggest that Romney doesn’t understand America.
docs.abstract: David Brooks Op-Ed column contends that leaked comments made by Mitt Romney at a private fund-raiser about Americans and the entitlement state seem to suggest that he does not know much about the culture of America; notes Romney is running a depressingly inept presidential campaign.
docs.snippet: Did you hear about Mitt Romney’s comments from a fund-raiser earlier this year? They seemed to suggest that Romney doesn’t understand America.

docs.lead_paragraph: Proving which initiatives work could turn the state into a model for others on how to cut Medicaid without harming the beneficiaries.
docs.abstract: Editorial holds New York State has substantially changed its Medicaid program in ways likely to improve the health of its poorest residents and rein in its enormous costs; urges Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services to allow the state to use the $10 billion in projected federal savings from its reforms, which, if spent wisely, could turn New York into a model on how to cut Medicaid without harming beneficiaries.
docs.snippet: Proving which initiatives work could turn the state into a model for others on how to cut Medicaid without harming the beneficiaries.
